questions.question: What is the main character's full name?
questions.explanation: The main character is Joe Spud, a 12-year-old billionaire boy.

questions.question: How old is Joe at the start of the story?
questions.explanation: The text says 'He was only 12, but he was ridiculously, preposterously rich.'

questions.question: What is the name of the product that made Joe's dad rich?
questions.explanation: Mr Spud invented 'Freshbum,' a moist on one side and dry on the other loo roll.

questions.question: What is Joe's best friend's name?
questions.explanation: Bob is the fat boy who becomes Joe's best friend at his new school.

questions.question: What did Mr Spud's job involve before he became rich?
questions.explanation: Mr Spud 'had to roll the paper around the cardboard inner tube' at a loo roll factory.

questions.question: What is the name of the posh school Joe used to attend?
questions.explanation: Joe attended 'St. Cuthbert's School for Boys' which cost £200,000 a term.

questions.question: Who runs the local newsagent shop?
questions.explanation: Raj runs the local newsagent shop where the boys go to buy chocolate.

questions.question: What are the names of the twin bullies?
questions.explanation: The Grubs are twin bullies named Dave and Sue Grub.

questions.question: What did Joe crash at the beginning of the story?
questions.explanation: Joe crashes his Formula One car while trying to eat a Mars bar and drive at the same time.

questions.question: How much pocket money does Joe get per week?
questions.explanation: The text lists '£100,000 a week pocket money' among Joe's possessions.

questions.question: What is the dinner lady's name?
questions.explanation: Mrs Trafe is the dinner lady whose cooking is described as truly revolting.

questions.question: What did Mr Spud put on his bald head?
questions.explanation: Mr Spud bought toupees for £10,000 each, including blonde, brown, ginger and afro options.

questions.question: What is the name of their enormous house?
questions.explanation: Mr Spud named their house 'Fresh Bum Towers' after his product.

questions.question: What chocolate bar does Joe buy for Bob at Raj's shop?
questions.explanation: Bob chooses 'a giant bar of Cadbury's Dairy Milk' which costs £3.20.

questions.question: What happened to Bob's dad?
questions.explanation: Bob tells Joe 'My dad died last year' from cancer.

questions.question: What is the history teacher's nickname?
questions.explanation: Miss Spite is called 'the Witch' by the students.

questions.question: How much did Mr Spud give Joe for his 12th birthday?
questions.explanation: Mr Spud initially gave one million but increased it to two million when Joe complained.

questions.question: Where did Bob's parents meet?
questions.explanation: Bob's mum 'works at Tesco, on the checkout. That's where she met my dad.'

questions.question: What animal did the Spuds have as a butler for a while?
questions.explanation: They 'even had a butler called Otis who was also an orangutan.'

questions.question: What does Joe really want for his birthday?
questions.explanation: When asked what he wants, Joe says 'A friend.'

questions.question: According to the story, Joe was quite fat because ---.
options: he could buy all the chocolate in the world
he ate too much fast food
questions.explanation: The text states 'He was quite fat, you see. Well, you would be, wouldn't you, if you could buy all the chocolate in the world.'

questions.question: At St Cuthbert's School, the posh kids bullied Joe because ---.
options: his dad made money from loo rolls which was considered vulgar
questions.explanation: The posh kids called Joe names like 'Bum-Boy' because 'his dad had made his money out of loo rolls. They said that was awfully vulgar.'

questions.question: Joe didn't arrive at his new school in a Rolls-Royce because ---.
options: he wanted to walk for exercise
he didn't want the other kids to know he was rich
questions.explanation: He didn't want to arrive by Rolls-Royce because 'That would be a pretty good hint to the other kids that he was rich.'

questions.question: During cross-country running, Joe paid Bob fifty pounds because ---.
options: Joe wanted Bob to come last so Joe wouldn't be last
questions.explanation: Joe had a stitch and didn't want to be last, so he paid Bob fifty pounds to 'come last.'

questions.question: Mr Spud invented Freshbum while working at the factory because ---.
options: he had lots of time to daydream during his boring job
another worker gave him the idea
questions.explanation: The text says 'The only good thing about working in a factory was that Mr Spud had lots of time to daydream. One day, he had a daydream that was to revolutionize bottom wiping forever.'

questions.question: When Joe's parents split up, his mother Carol left because ---.
options: she was unhappy with the money
she had been having an affair with Joe's Cub Scout leader
Mr Spud was too busy working
questions.explanation: Carol 'had been having a torrid affair with Joe's Cub Scout leader, Alan.'

questions.question: Raj recognized Joe from a magazine because ---.
options: Joe's photo was in the Sunday Times rich list as Britain's richest child
questions.explanation: Raj found the Sunday Times rich list showing 'Britain's richest children, number one, Joe Spud, age twelve, Freshbum heir, estimated worth ten billion.'

questions.question: The Grubs threw Bob into a wheelie bin because ---.
options: they wanted to steal his chocolate
questions.explanation: The Grubs demanded 'Give us your chocolate' and after taking it, 'they deposited him into the wheelie bin.'

questions.question: Bob didn't tell anyone about the bullying because ---.
options: he didn't know who to tell
the Grubs threatened to really beat him up if he told
questions.explanation: Bob said 'The Grubs said if I ever told anyone that they would really beat me up. They know where I live.'

questions.question: When Bob found out Joe was a billionaire, he gave back the fifty pounds because ---.
options: he didn't care about money, he just liked hanging out with Joe
questions.explanation: Bob said 'I don't want your money... I just liked hanging out with you today.'

questions.question: No one ate in the school canteen because ---.
options: Mrs Trafe's cooking was truly revolting
questions.explanation: The text says 'The kids in the school would rather die than eat anything she cooked.'

questions.question: Mr Spud used to make birthday presents for Joe from loo roll inner tubes because ---.
options: the family was so poor they couldn't afford real toys
questions.explanation: The text explains 'Because the family was so poor, Mr Spud used to make birthday and Christmas presents for his son from the loo roll inner tubes.'

questions.question: Joe wanted to attend a normal school because ---.
options: the posh school was too far away
he hoped to make friends and be treated like a normal kid
his dad couldn't afford St Cuthbert's anymore
questions.explanation: Joe says 'I want to go to a normal school with normal kids. I want to make a friend, Dad.'

questions.question: The Spuds' house was so large that ---.
options: it took five minutes just to drive up the driveway
they needed helicopters to travel inside
questions.explanation: The text says 'It took five minutes just to motor up the drive.'

questions.question: Joe couldn't get on the bus because ---.
options: he didn't know which bus to take
the driver wouldn't accept a £50 note for a £2 fare
he was too fat to fit
questions.explanation: 'Joe hadn't realised that a £50 note was not going to be welcome to pay for a £2 bus fare and had to get off the bus.'

questions.question: Bob's mum works two jobs as a Tesco checkout worker and ---.
options: a cleaner at an old people's home
questions.explanation: Bob says 'She's got another job too. She's a cleaner at an old people's home in the evenings.'

questions.question: When Miss Spite discovered Joe didn't have his homework, she gave him ---.
options: 15 minutes to get his essay brought to school
questions.explanation: Miss Spite says 'I will give you 15 minutes exactly to place said essay in my hand.'

questions.question: At cross-country running, Bob appeared in his vest and Y-fronts because ---.
options: he forgot his kit at home
someone had hidden his running kit
he was trying to be funny
questions.explanation: When Mr Bruce asked about his kit, Bob answered 'Someone must have hidden it, sir.'

questions.question: The kids at school chanted 'Blob' at Bob because ---.
options: it was his nickname making fun of his weight
questions.explanation: The kids cruelly chanted 'Blob, blob, blob' as Bob finished last in cross-country, mocking him.

questions.question: According to the Sunday Times rich list, Joe's estimated worth was ---.
questions.explanation: The magazine listed 'Joe Spud, age twelve, Freshbum heir, estimated worth ten billion.'

questions.question: What does Joe's list of possessions (100-inch TVs, 500 trainers, crocodiles, etc.) reveal about wealth?
options: That having endless material possessions doesn't guarantee friendship or happiness
That rich people are always happy
That everyone should want to be rich
questions.explanation: Despite having everything money can buy, Joe has no friends and is lonely, showing material wealth doesn't equal happiness.

questions.question: Why is it significant that Joe and Bob both ended up last in cross-country running?
options: It shows they are both bad at sports
It becomes a bonding experience that starts their friendship based on shared experience rather than money
It proves the PE teacher was unfair
It means they should both quit school
questions.explanation: The shared experience of struggling together creates the foundation for their friendship, which is based on understanding rather than wealth.

questions.question: What does the contrast between St Cuthbert's and the local comprehensive school represent?
options: The difference between class-based exclusion and genuine human connection
That posh schools are always bad
questions.explanation: At St Cuthbert's, Joe was bullied for being 'new money,' but at the comprehensive, he could find genuine friendship based on personality rather than social class.

questions.question: What theme is illustrated by Bob returning the fifty pounds after learning Joe is a billionaire?
options: That poor people don't want money
That true friendship values the person over their wealth
questions.explanation: Bob's refusal shows he values Joe for who he is, not what he has, demonstrating the story's theme about authentic friendship.

questions.question: What is ironic about Mr Spud insisting on eating expensive food like caviar despite hating it?
options: Rich people always love expensive food
He's trying to appear wealthy by adopting behaviors he thinks rich people do, even when it makes him unhappy
questions.explanation: Mr Spud admits caviar is 'absolutely disgusting' but says 'we are rich, son. We have to eat all this posh stuff now,' showing how wealth can disconnect people from genuine enjoyment.

questions.question: Why is it significant that Bob's dad used to joke about going into Tesco for milk but leaving with a wife?
options: It represents how genuine love can develop from ordinary circumstances, contrasting with Mr Spud's superficial relationships
questions.explanation: This contrasts with Mr Spud dating Page Three girls for their looks, showing the difference between authentic love and superficial relationships bought with money.

questions.question: What does Mrs Trafe's revolting menu (gerbils on toast, hair lasagna, etc.) add to the story's humor?
options: It makes fun of school food
It uses absurd exaggeration to create comedy while showing the boys can bond over shared experiences
It's meant to be taken seriously
It shows the school needs more funding
questions.explanation: The ridiculously gross menu uses hyperbole for comic effect while creating another shared experience for Joe and Bob to bond over.

questions.question: What does Joe's decision to hide his wealth at the new school reveal about his character?
options: He is ashamed of being rich
He understands that money creates artificial relationships and wants to be valued for himself
He thinks being poor is better
questions.explanation: Joe learned from St Cuthbert's that money affects how people treat him, so he wants a fresh start where he can be judged on his personality.

questions.question: What is the significance of Joe's dad buying toupees that make him look like he has 'a dead rodent on his head'?
options: Money can't buy authenticity or self-acceptance, and trying to appear different than you are looks foolish
He should have bought more expensive ones
questions.explanation: The toupee symbolizes how wealth is used to mask insecurities, but the result is ridiculous rather than convincing.

questions.question: Why might Bob's advice that 'the best way to beat bullies is to stand up to them' be both wise and problematic?
options: While it shows courage, the reality is that standing up to the Grubs could get Bob seriously hurt, highlighting the gap between ideal advice and practical reality
questions.explanation: The advice is morally sound but practically dangerous for Bob, which is why Joe thinks there might be 'another way' using his resources.

questions.question: What does the book suggest about 'old money' versus 'new money' through the attitudes at St Cuthbert's?
options: Class prejudice exists even among the wealthy, with inherited wealth looking down on earned wealth
questions.explanation: The posh boys with inherited wealth consider Joe's earned fortune 'vulgar,' showing that class snobbery creates hierarchies even among the rich.

questions.question: What does the detail about the orangutan butler 'Otis' who 'had to be given the sack' suggest about the Spuds' lifestyle?
options: Their wealth has led to absurd, thoughtless decisions that don't work out practically
questions.explanation: Having an orangutan butler is an example of ridiculous extravagance that was impractical, showing how extreme wealth leads to absurd choices.

questions.question: Why is it significant that Joe kept a 'sad-looking little loo roll space rocket' his dad made when they were poor?
options: It represents a connection to a time when love was expressed through effort rather than money
He forgot to throw it away
questions.explanation: The homemade gift represents the authentic parent-child bond from before wealth, contrasting with the £2 million birthday check.

questions.question: What does Miss Spite's love of teacher catchphrases reveal about her character?
options: She enjoys power and control, using authority phrases for her own satisfaction rather than students' benefit
questions.explanation: Miss Spite uses catchphrases with 'evil relish' and is 'desperate for someone to have failed,' showing she enjoys punishing students rather than teaching them.

questions.question: What is the effect of making one of the Grub twins female but having them be indistinguishable?
options: It's a mistake in the story
It creates comedy while commenting on how bullying behavior makes people seem inhuman and identical
It shows twins are always identical
questions.explanation: The joke that Dave and Sue are indistinguishable despite being different genders uses absurdity to dehumanize the bullies while creating humor.

questions.question: What does Joe's guilt about paying Bob to come last, and his desire to 'make up for it,' reveal about his development?
options: He's learning that real friendship isn't transactional and wants to help Bob genuinely
questions.explanation: Joe feels guilty about using money to solve problems and wants to help Bob with the bullies in a way that demonstrates genuine friendship.

questions.question: What social commentary does the story make through Mr Spud dating 'Sapphire, 19, from Essex'?
options: Wealth attracts superficial relationships where both parties may be using each other for status
Page Three models are all the same
questions.explanation: The 27-year age gap and Sapphire's description ('likes shopping, hates thinking') suggests wealth attracts relationships based on status rather than genuine connection.

questions.question: Why does the author include the detail that Joe 'had spent so long living a life of wealth and privilege' that he wondered how to 'fit in with these kids'?
options: To show Joe is better than other kids
To highlight how wealth can isolate people from normal experiences and create social anxiety
To prove rich kids can't make friends
To show public schools are scary
questions.explanation: This shows how extreme wealth creates isolation and makes normal social interactions feel unfamiliar and challenging.

questions.question: What is the deeper meaning of Joe asking for a 'friend' as his birthday present?
options: It reveals that the one thing money cannot buy is genuine human connection
He doesn't know what he wants
questions.explanation: Despite having unlimited money, Joe cannot purchase the thing he most wants, highlighting the story's central theme about money's limitations.

questions.question: What is the overall message of Billionaire Boy about wealth and happiness?
options: Money provides material comfort but cannot replace genuine human relationships, kindness, and being valued for who you are
Everyone should give away their money
questions.explanation: The story shows that while poverty has hardships (like Bob's family), wealth without authentic relationships and identity leads to loneliness and dissatisfaction.
